thread.title: Devastated mum relives heartbreak of going into labour on her wedding night and losing the her baby
thread.title_full: Devastated mum relives heartbreak of going into labour on her wedding night and losing the her baby

author: Scarlet Howes
title: Devastated mum relives heartbreak of going into labour on her wedding night and losing the her baby
text:
News Devastated mum relives heartbreak of going into labour on her wedding night and losing the her baby Victoria and her new husband Thomas Holland were faced with the heartbreaking decision whether to let their newborn son carry on Share Victoria Holland (middle, with second son Reuben) (Photo: Birmingham Mail) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A mum who went into labour on her wedding night and lost her baby has spoken of her tragedy for the first time. 
Victoria Holland had been excitedly planning for the arrival of her little boy when she started to feel achy and tired before her wedding day. 
At 27 weeks pregnant she just put it down to being so busy. 
The wedding, at Dudley Register Office, went beautifully but later that evening Victoria’s pains became significantly worse so she went to hospital to get checked out. 
Within five minutes of arriving, she’d gone into labour. Read More Victoria with her second son Reuben, whose birth was also endured complications (Photo: Birmingham Mail) 
Victoria, 28, from Oldbury, told Birmingham Mail : "It all happened really quickly. 
"I'd called the hospital and they thought it was probably a water infection. 
“I couldn’t believe it when I went into labour.” 
Freddie was born at 1.35am that morning and weighed just 2lb 10oz. 
He was whisked straight to an incubator in neonatal as he was so small. 
Three days later, doctors discovered there were high levels of acid in his blood. 
Sadly, at just four days old, Freddie’s organs started shutting down and Victoria and her husband Thomas were faced with the devastating decision whether to let him carry on or to switch off his CPAP life support machine. Read More She has had Freddie’s name, footprint and birth date tattooed onto her arm with the words ‘Love you to the moon and back’ (Photo: Birmingham Mail) 
“It was the hardest decision we’ve ever had to make,” says Victoria. 
“But we could see how much pain he was in, and that made it an easier decision. 
“No parent wants their child to suffer. 
The doctors said the likelihood was he would pass away at some point. 
“The vicar came to baptise him with our family there and then they turned off the machines so everyone could have cuddles. 
“He was alive for two and a half hours when he passed away in my arms.” Read More "I ache every minute": Mum whose son asked her what's for dinner before committing suicide shares heartbreak 
The heartbroken couple spent a few hours in hospital with Freddie where they bathed and dressed him. 
They also put together a memory box including teddies and a book called Guess How Much I love You. 
Victoria has Freddie’s name, footprint and birth date tattooed onto her arm with the words ‘Love you to the moon and back’. 
Mum Victoria faced more difficult times when at 33 weeks pregnant with her second son she feared she was going to lose the baby. 
Following another quick delivery, Reuben was born on September 20, 2016 weighing 5lb. 
He was whisked into an incubator before Victoria could even hold him. Read More The mum is now joining the #Help100moms campaign with Edward's Trust which hopes to raise £5k for 100 sessions helping mums who have lost children (Photo: Birmingham Mail) 
Victoria said: "I was filled with fear." 
“Freddie was alive for just four days – was the same thing going to happen again? 
“I hadn’t had chance to cuddle Freddie until the day we turned off the machines.” 
Thankfully, Victoria did get to hold Reuben on day four but he remained in an incubator for two weeks. 
Then, at last, the couple were able to bring their precious baby home. 
“I was anxious but it was amazing to bring him home.” 
Today, Reuben is a healthy six month old and Victoria has a tattoo on her back to mark her ‘rainbow baby’ – a baby who brings hope after a storm. Like us on Facebook
